high_relevance.description: Examines how social structure and network position influence outcomes, information flow, and opportunities
high_relevance.relevance_to_rqs: Directly addresses RQ1 by explaining how network centrality, weak ties, and structural holes affect progression from periphery to core
high_relevance.relevance_to_model: Can model network metrics (centrality, density, clustering) as stocks/flows affecting knowledge access and promotion opportunities
high_relevance.phd_contribution: Quantifies social capital effects on OSS career progression; reveals network bottlenecks in developer advancement

high_relevance.description: Human motivation framework focusing on autonomy, competence, and relatedness as basic psychological needs
high_relevance.relevance_to_rqs: Addresses RQ1 motivational drivers and RQ2 intervention design by identifying what sustains developer engagement
high_relevance.relevance_to_model: Model psychological need satisfaction as reinforcing loops affecting contribution quality and persistence
high_relevance.phd_contribution: Links motivational psychology to technical contribution patterns; explains why some developers persist while others drop out

high_relevance.description: Examines the interdependence between social and technical systems and their joint optimization
high_relevance.relevance_to_rqs: Directly addresses RQ3 by modeling how social coordination failures create technical vulnerabilities
high_relevance.relevance_to_model: Model social-technical alignment as a critical variable affecting system reliability and security
high_relevance.phd_contribution: Provides integrated framework for analyzing how social dynamics create technical debt and security risks

adjacent_opportunities.description: Organization's ability to recognize, assimilate, and apply new external knowledge
adjacent_opportunities.why_adjacent: Focuses on organizational rather than individual learning, but individual absorptive capacity affects progression
adjacent_opportunities.novel_angle: Views developer progression as dependent on both individual learning capacity and community knowledge-sharing structures
adjacent_opportunities.phd_contribution: Links individual learning trajectories to community knowledge infrastructure

adjacent_opportunities.description: Explains how complex interventions become routinely embedded in social contexts
adjacent_opportunities.why_adjacent: Originally for healthcare interventions, but applicable to OSS process interventions
adjacent_opportunities.novel_angle: Provides framework for understanding why some onboarding interventions succeed while others fail to normalize
adjacent_opportunities.phd_contribution: Explains intervention sustainability and institutionalization in volunteer communities

adjacent_opportunities.description: Explains how organizations operating in hazardous environments achieve exceptional safety records
adjacent_opportunities.why_adjacent: Originally for nuclear/aviation, but OSS communities face similar reliability demands
adjacent_opportunities.novel_angle: Views OSS communities as HROs that must maintain reliability despite volunteer turnover and distributed coordination
adjacent_opportunities.phd_contribution: Applies HRO principles to distributed volunteer communities; identifies reliability-enhancing social practices

cross_domain_inspiration.parallel: Community development through pioneer species to climax communities mirrors developer progression
cross_domain_inspiration.transfer_potential: Models community resilience to member turnover; identifies critical transition points in community development
cross_domain_inspiration.rationale: Provides novel perspective on community lifecycle and resilience to developer churn

cross_domain_inspiration.parallel: How biological systems detect and respond to threats while maintaining normal function
cross_domain_inspiration.transfer_potential: Metaphor for how OSS communities detect vulnerabilities while maintaining development velocity
cross_domain_inspiration.rationale: Offers fresh perspective on balancing innovation with security in distributed systems

cross_domain_inspiration.parallel: Examines how human and non-human actors form networks that produce scientific knowledge
cross_domain_inspiration.transfer_potential: Reveals how tools, bots, and infrastructure shape developer progression and community dynamics
cross_domain_inspiration.rationale: Radically reframes progression as co-constructed by human and technological actors

phd_strategy.rationale: These three theories directly address the major gaps identified: motivation/orientation (SDT), social structure (SNT), and security/safety (STS). They complement existing CoP and SECI models while being empirically grounded and modelable in system dynamics.
phd_strategy.integration_strategy: Use SDT to explain motivational drivers within CoP participation; apply SNT to model social capital accumulation in SECI knowledge flows; employ STS to analyze how social-technical misalignments create vulnerabilities during developer transitions.
phd_strategy.expected_impact: Creates comprehensive multi-level framework connecting individual motivation, social structure, and technical outcomes; enables predictive modeling of intervention effects and vulnerability emergence.
